reviews.review_title: An inaccurate Courtroom Drama that Borders on the Ridiculous
reviews.content: I know that many people have commented on this movie giving it rave reviews, but I really must disagree. I won't comment on the acting- It's personal opinion whether it's over the top, or realistic, or whatever- the court scenes are my main issue with the film. Throughout the movie, I found myself wondering how the two lawyers managed to get so high up in the business; they neglected to research their cases at all, and seemed to believe that the only measure of a good lawyer was how loud they could yell. In fact, they seemed to feel that they didn't even have to make a decent point as long as they were yelling. At one point, the lawyer played by Tracy tries to make a point, and sees that the jury does not understand... and then does not explain it. The lawyers also took to arguing between themselves in the middle of the courtroom- and the judge let them. Furthermore I felt that I could have done a better job defending the teacher, and I am not even close to being a lawyer. I'm sure this is a very well made movie, and the actors are certainly excellent... but to call it thought provoking and almost perfect is going too far.

I think this an excellent drama, but not a history, and it does not pretend to be. This film is not based on The Scopes Monkey Trial of 1925, but the 'Jerome Lawrence' (qv) and 'Robert E. Lee' (qv) play of 1950.  Although play and film use chunks of transcript  the Drummond/Brady cross-examination is almost verbatim Darrow's questioning of Bryan  the play shows its separate evolution. Written at the heart of the Anti-Communist Witch-Hunts the reason Drummond makes an impassioned plea for the right to think becomes obvious. To highlight their anti-witchhunt message Lawrence and Lee took a lot of licence in making the townspeople very bigoted, and in dramatising the circumstances of `Bertram Gates' arrest. As a result, some Christians condemn the film as an attack on their religion.  Rather it highlights the state of society a quarter of a century after the events nominally depicted. The play, although written in 1950 could not be performed until 1955; since when it has been filmed and staged several times, most recently in Broadway in 1995 with 'Tony Randall' (qv) and a 1999 TV movie starring 'Jack Lemmon' (qv) and 'George C Scott' (qv)

Great trial fireworks, all provided by the able lawyers who actually tried this case, are half-smothered in the labored surrounding plot.  The best part of the movie, and of the play, was written by Darrow and Bryan long before Lawrence and Lee encumbered it with banal prejudice.  Yes, it's a great shout for open-mindedness, so long as open-mindedness is in the end Darwinian.  I don't mean to take a position in the culture wars over evolution; its enough to note that this film plays from a loaded deck (and for the most part does so pretty clumsily).

reviews.review_title: One of the Truly Great Films of American Cinema
reviews.content: No special effects! No gun play! Only two of the greatest actors giving among their best performances in the timeless story of the true "Trial of the Century." I tend to disagree with many posters who denigrate the performance of Gene Kelly as E.K. Hornbeck. That he pales alongside Tracy and March is understandable. Who wouldn't? I find his portrayal to be understated and containing just the right touches of cynicism and a realism. His character is significantly expanded from the play. One example is the scene where Hornbeck tells Drummond that after he (Hornbeck) dies he won't be un-mourned. Dtrummond will be at the funeral, he says, because that's the kind of guy he is. This illustrates perfectly the differences between the journalist who writes of injustice, but mainly it seems for his own enjoyment, and the crusading lawyer who takes up unpopular causes because it is the right thing to do.I have loved this play since I read it in high school, and the movie with it's great stars, does not disappoint.

I have seen this film about six times and my opinion as to its' quality decreases with each viewing.Frederic March over-acted in 'Best Years of Our Lives' (which, minus March, I would have given a '10') and does the same in 'Inherit The Wind.' He is a stage actor and old-school Rod Steiger. Spencer Tracy is from Milwaukee where people don't give a damn what others think about them or their city. His performance was superb as it was in all of his films.Dick York was mis-cast as Cates (Scopes). He is a comedian who co-starred with Barbara Eden in 'Bewitched.' Harry Morgan was mis-cast as the judge (far too young for a God-fearing southern judge) and the sidekick to Jack Webb in 'Dragnet.' In 1960, movies began to be more realistic, yet the name of the the town and the characters' names were changed to protect the 'innocent.' Anyone with a brain knows the lawyers were William Jennings Bryant (prosecution) and Clarence Darrow (defense) and the teacher was named Scopes, not Cates. These scenarios make the film almost laughable. In fact, I look upon this film as a comedy 'teaser' except for the performance of Spencer Tracy. Gene Kelly, a great dancer and so-so actor, was entirely mis-cast as the Baltimore reporter.Lastly, a belief or dis-belief in evolution is a matter of faith. A belief or dis-belief in God is a matter of faith. There is no right or wrong, but if there was no religion the world would be a much better place.

reviews.review_title: Intelligent, thoughtful and entertaining- Steve Bethell
reviews.content: The film itself is loosely based upon the Scopes trial of 1925 and is in essence an examination of two opposing forces -mankind's willingness to think for itself as against its willingness to follow simple doctrines which can thereby give rise inflexible intolerance.A key statement in the film is that 'fanaticism and ignorance are forever busy and need feeding'. Religion in this instance is used as an example of an avenue toward intolerance whereby mankind takes the fresh and illuminating thoughts of the bible and translates them (or more accurately allows others to translate them) into a rigid set of rules which are thereby man-made whilst assuming the aura of god-given.Directed by Stanley Kramer and starring two hollywood heavyweights, Spencer Tracy and Fredric March, the film benefits from tight dialogue, a claustrophobic courthouse set and a rumbustuous performance by the leads who spend a great deal of time trying to outdo each other. With a strong supporting cast (only Gene Kelly looked uncomfortable and he passed the comment that 'he had finally stepped out of his class") the film is a quality product of the kind rarely seen these days.Whilst the set was officially closed, it was packed to the rafters with hollywood luminaries such as Frank Sinatra who spent days watching the two stars slug it out and give a master class in screen performing. The film's climax is a set piece confrontation where the issues are examined with intelligence and wit and it is worth recording the scenes between March on the witness stand, and Tracy examining him, as an example of two actors at the height of their profession.Given the odor of political correctness where free speech is stifled, given the intolerance of religious leaders who have translated Islamic and Christian teachings to suit their own narrow prejudices, and given the intolerance of leaders towards those who try to think for themselves, this film is as fresh and relevant today as it was in 1960. Watch it and think. Think then learn.

reviews.review_title: This is a great movie, and that is the problem.
reviews.content:
If we were lucky enough not to have opinions, or worse certitudes, about Darwin or creationism, we could enjoy "Inherit the wind" for what it is, a well directed vehicle for some of the best actors of its time. Stunning camera work, punchy dialogs, some award worthy secondary roles acting, Akins is a must see, and all the know how that made Tracy, March and Kelly household names.Yes, we could have a jolly good time of a movie. And we should, from the opening credits, with the astute use of the song "gimme that old time religion" to highlight the old west walk of the town officials from court to school. Followed by the 2 hours long compelling mix of film noir esthetics, the use of shadows and.slightly unbalanced camera angles, and dialogs worthy of the best social commentary blended with great comedy movies, with the right mix of one liners and speeches.The movie offers passion, be it for the belief in science or the belief in religion, but also for a more cynical belief in the power of words. In the end the three main characters are first and foremost men of words, and the actors do leave room to consider if the characters are not more interesting in listening to their own voice than to whatever principle they stand for. It also offers satire both of small town mentality and big city arrogance, one gets a feel that the seriousness shown by the townsfolk vs the levity of the city fellas is actually used to highlight the overall issue of simple belief vs principled cause. And if we do take a step backward from the actuality of the debate, this is what makes this a great movie.And this is also what makes it a problem. There is an exchange between the lawyer for evolution (Tracy) and the wife of the prosecutor for creationism (Eldridge):
-He still has a very loud voice (says Tracy of his opponent)
-He still has something to say (answers the wife)
And still, these three people are and remain old time friends. And that encapsulates the issue. In these times when school, science, religion, freedom of expression and excess of principles are again colliding in the worst ways, it seems we can't pick friends over sides anymore.Let's be provocative and summarize the movie, ignoring the issue, an outlaw teacher advances his beliefs, in contradiction to the laws of his place. He's attacked by opinionated no nuance officials led by a public figure who wants to make good of the occasion, he is defended by loud mouthed lawyer and journalist who want to make a point. Nots so clear cut then. But this is because that is not the point of the movie, neither is the choice between evolution and creationism, this movie is about the confrontation of ideas, the confrontation of how to communicate, the confrontation of voices.The importance of this movie is not who's right or wrong, it is that debate, public and private, prevails, and, wherever, whatever, we come from, that is what should make us humans!

Inherit the Wind is a beautiful, artistic movie.  This is a film that stimulates the mind with thought provoking ideas.  Among many other ponderings, it suggests that fighting for a cause can be crucial, while fighting individual people will only result in pain.March, Tracy and Kelly are a spectacularly dynamic trio, each making his character a vital mix of human emotions, transcending the black and white in which the world sees him.  We as viewers are presented with this concept through the black and white cinematography itself.The material around which the story is centered is naturally controversial, even today.  It's actually quite impressive that a movie studio was willing to pay for its production in 1960. No matter your beliefs, this is a movie every thinking person owes it to him or herself to see.

reviews.review_title: A Powerful Film That Has Remained Relevant With The Passing Of Time.
reviews.content: In the final decade of his career, Spencer Tracy would work exclusively with producer and director Stanley Kramer, roles that would turn out to be among his most memorable. However, it's also worth mentioning that in addition to Tracy's talent, he's supporting by a cast of very talented individuals, who are all perfect in their own aspects. And furthermore, the film itself is something that in many ways, is still as relevant now as it was back when it was released.Inherit The Wind is a powerful film that features the zenith of talent at its best, and features a subject that has becoming increasingly more prominent in today's society. The film is an engaging and thrilling involvement that is essentially a clash of philosophies, more specifically, it's the right to think against those who swear by creationism, a battle between the ones who dare to think for themselves versus the ones who refuse to have their beliefs challenged. This, combined with fabulous acting, is used to create a compelling film that some might say has a place among the best in American cinema.The film is a dramatization of the real-life story of John T. Scopes, a Tennessee schoolteacher who was arrested for teaching Darwin's theory of evolution in school. The trial the followed became both a media sensation, as well as match of minds between two famous men, Clarence Darrow, who represented the defense, and William Jennings Bryan, who represented the prosecution. Even though the film does make several deviations from real life for the purpose of drama, there's still no denying that the film is a powerful experience that in many ways, is still relevant, primarily in regards to the creationists who dislike having their beliefs challenged. In addition to that, it's also a powerhouse for talent, featuring some incredibly gifted individuals giving the performances of their careers.What makes the film hold up is how it manages to say relevant. The film basically represents a time where politics was dominated by religion, and while the idea sounds preposterous, it's very true to how it was in real life, and it's actually very disturbing. There are several scenes in the film where the townsfolk are shown demonstrating their beliefs against Dick York's character (the one based on Scopes), with many even calling for him to be hanged, with Tracy's character also being targeted as well. There's also a rather chilling supporting role from Claude Akins, who plays the town preacher, who gives several unnerving and intimidating speeches about how those who believe in evolution are doomed to hell, even going as far as to say that about his own daughter. There's also a scene in court in which Tracy is held in contempt after being pushed to his limits and launching into a speech about ignorance and fanaticism, which is something else that is ever so relevant in the present. However, it should be mentioned that the film isn't against religion itself, but instead against the aforementioned ideas of fanaticism and ignorance, which is a mindset that is incredibly toxic.As compelling as this dramatization of the Monkey Trial is to see, it's also very engaging to see what is essentially a duel between two of the greatest actors in the history of cinema, Spencer Tracy and Frederic March. The two of them were perfect, with it being hard to decide which one was better, since it seemed as if they were both trying to upstage each other. In a rare dramatic role, Gene Kelly was stupendous as a reporter who arrives in town to cover the trial, who throws shade as the creationists. Kelly's performance seems to be rather ironic, in which he takes stabs at the people who loved his musical performances but have dogmatic opinions against those who think differently from themselves. However, Kelly is in a way, like them because of his support for Dick York's character. The aforementioned Claude Akins plays what is probably his best role as a firebrand preacher who creates a divide with his own daughter because of her love for Dick York's character, the one who is on trial for daring to go against the belief of creationists, and what's unfortunate, is that there are many people like him in the present day. Special mention goes to Harry Morgan, who plays the judge presiding over the trial, as well as Noah Berry Jr., who plays a farmer who helps out Tracy becomes of something personal. In fact, I don't think that Stanley Kramer could've picked a better cast if he tried, because everyone in the film was as perfect as one could imagine.Ultimately, Inherit The Wind is an excellent film that has incredible staying power in regards to its messages. As I mentioned before, it's not an indictment of religion, but of religious fanaticism, and those who criticize the right to think. In addition, it's also worth seeing to see a very talented cast perform in what you might say are the roles of their careers, as there wasn't a single performance that faltered. The film is definitely one that should be seen, because of how great it is, but it's also one that might disturb its audience, both because of some of the subject matter, and because of how it's managed to stay relevant.

reviews.review_title: Film downgraded by religious zealots which is sad
reviews.content: Two wonderful actors, great direction and an excellent supporting cast yet the religious zealots, who are being addressed in this film,again come out on the attack. In their childlike reviews they fail to talk about the merits of the film or lack of such but rather are offended by the subject matter. This is exactly why the film remains pertinent in 2017. Interesting subject matter true but brilliant actors who are past their prime and can still act circles around many. I also was taken with the women of the movie. Very fine acting.

i show this film in my biology classes as a part of my evolution section. immediately the kids hate it because its in black and white and they do not recognize any of the actors.  However by the end of the film they are abuzz about how good it is and wonder why they haven't seen it before.  Truly one of the best acted films of all  time.  How can you go wrong with two time oscar winners spencer tracy and fredric march.  gene kelly ain't bad either. for a great film check this out!!!

I'm not a Christian, first and foremost. But I believe in God, second and foremost. I also think Darwin's theory is just that, a theory, and quite a nonsense theory, third and foremost (and no, I'm not trying to start any argument here. I'd still think it was nonsense even if I was agnostic or atheist or a buddhist, no offense to anyone.) I'm saying this to point out that I don't really support either "side" of the argument in this film.This wonderful courtroom drama is set in the Bible belt, where a high school teacher tries to teach about Darwin's Origin Of The Species in school (therefore breaking the law) and is imprisoned. An opportunist, has-been conservative politician sees this a chance to get in the public's favor once again, and announces that he'll be the prosecutor's attorney (or however that works in the US system). The accused teacher, in despair, writes to a newspaper and they also send a famous liberal lawyer, for his defense.The movie obviously takes sides here, presenting the bigotry in the small town in a harsh light, and taking the liberal side. But the politics of the movie is only a minor point, the real star is the great direction, photography, script and acting. Spencer Tracy is amazing as the defense lawyer bashing every point made by the prosecution, although the whole town, even the judge, acts like them. The dialogue is great, and no matter whose ideas you support, or even if you have no interest in the subject at all, it still keeps you interested. I just kept sighing, saying wow, they really used to make movies back then.It's Spencer Tracy's movie, but the supporting cast is no less stellar. Gene Kelly, in particular. He plays the most cynical reporter I've seen in a movie, a break from his typecasting of goody-two-shoes dancers and hopeless romantics. He has the best lines in the movie.Definitely recommended.

reviews.review_title: Riveting performance by Spencer Tracy. Brilliant script. Excellent direction by Stanley Kramer.
reviews.content: "Inherit The Wind" is one of the greatest films ever made. I consider Spencer Tracy the greatest actor of them all. In this film, the power and depth of his performance is incredible. Fredric March's performance is powerful, as well. I think the script was intelligently written...fast-paced dialogue, witty, thought-provoking. Stanley Kramer's direction is masterful, as always. This remains one of my top ten favorite films. It gets better every time I see it.

The discussion of creation vs evolution has been going on for quite sometime and it was interesting to see one such clash which happened long time ago. I am someone who believes in creation and I was keen to understand which side the movie was tilting towards. It was good to note it took a balanced approach where it is difficult to do so and it fought for the right to think.We get to see some great performances. It does drag on sometimes. For me who loves classics this movie is another reason why I like old movies.

This movie has first gathered a number of distinguished actors that were perfect for their roles. Tracy and Marsch illustrated the intense debate of religion and the mind's free thinking (Darwinism)with a realistic manner that delt with all the corners of the subjects. I've never seen such an elaborate debate, that deserves the highest of credits.

reviews.review_title: The great monkey trial: great actors, great story.
reviews.content: After seeing this for the story, go back and watch it again, just for the acting: March and Tracy, the two greatest film actors of all time. See the subtle easy way March becomes the great William Jennings Bryan.  If you are for the religious right you will hate the way Tracy bates him.  Tracy, as Clarence Darrow for the defense, is everything we wish Darrow would have been (unlike Clarence, Spencer was never caught "acting").  Seldom do we get a chance to see two such great actors go head to head, like prize fighters in the ring. Every film actor should see this movie to learn how to BE the character rather than ACT it.  Almost as convincing, is Gene Kelly as a newspaper reporter (a composite of several real ones).  In the role of Bryan's wife is March's own wife, Florence Eldridge, sweet, understanding and loving, with patient dignity, in counterpoint to the anger of the crowd. With March and Tracy in the leads there is not much Dick York has to do but sit in the court room and look sad, even though director Stanley Kramer might have done more with him as the trial's defendant; but to give the great ones the most "face time" was a good choice.  Whether you are a lawyer, teacher, school board member, or a citizen advocate for freedom of speech, buy this movie, or rent it, but watch it.  5 thumbs up!  My true test of any movie is this: can I watch it again and again, and still learn something new each time?  This one never fails to absorb me and teach me.

reviews.review_title: Ingredients for a great film, add Spencer Tracy and stir!!!
reviews.content: Spencer Tracy and Fredric March are two aging lawyers that are old friends, but now they find themselves at odds with each other in a southern small town courtroom. The film is based on the notorious Scopes Monkey Trial of 1925, though the character names are changed, where a high school teacher, Dick York, is brought up on charges of heressy for teaching his students Charles Darwin's Theory of Evolution. March is grand as the bible-thumping southern attorney prosecuting York, while Tracy is great, as always, as the big city lawyer who defends the unfortunate biology teacher. Gene Kelly is interestingly, and successfully, cast as the venomous lawyer from Baltimore who finds all around him to be a fair target of his jaded cynicism. Claude Akins ably plays the town's fire and brimstone preacher, while Harry Morgan is solid as the presiding judge on the case. As with most court films it can be a bit too talky at times, but with this cast, let 'em talk!
